org.magelan.drawing
Interface DrawingElement

All Known Subinterfaces:
Entity, ExplodableEntity, RotatableEntity
All Known Implementing Classes:
AbstractDrawingElement, CircleElement, CircleEntity, DefaultEntity, EllipseElement, EllipseEntity, FillElement, HatchEntity, ImageEntity, InsertEntity, LabelEntity, LineElement, LineEntity, PathElement, PathEntity, PointElement, PointEntity, PolyLineEntity, RectangleElement, RectangleEntity, TextElement, TextEntity, ViewEntity
public interface DrawingElement

An interface, representing an element of a drawing. It provides rendering functionallity and can be queried regarding the geometry of the element. Drawing elements are stored in DrawingModels and their rendering is managed by DrawingRenderers. It is important to note that though elements are free to set the styling that should be used for their rendering, this should be an exception, not a rule. It is a task of each element to define its proper geometry shape, but leave decoration of the shape to the renderer.

Version:
1.0, 04/2004
Author:
Assen Antov
See Also:
DrawingModel, DrawingRenderer

Method Summary
 java.awt.Shape getShape()
          Used to obtain a Shape instance, representing the element.
 void paint(java.awt.Graphics2D g, DrawingModel d)
          A graphics renderer of the element.
 

Method Detail

getShape

java.awt.Shape getShape()
Used to obtain a Shape instance, representing the element. The coordinates defining the Shape are in model space (not scaled, rotated or transformed in any other way).

Returns:
a Shape instance, representing the element

paint

void paint(java.awt.Graphics2D g,
           DrawingModel d)
A graphics renderer of the element. By convention this method will assume that the parameter graphics context is fully configured, i.e. the proper transform, clipping shape, color, stroke and alpha shall be set before calling the paint method. Thus the painting method for most of the elements will simply draw element's shape to the graphics context: g.draw(getShape());

The DrawingModel parameter will not be normally used. It is provided for more complex / composite elements like groups, blocks and views, that will need to paint a number of shapes, possibly from different layers. Therefore such elements will need access to layers, styles, etc. from the DrawingModel they belong to. Those elements may configure the graphics context themselves.

Parameters:
g - graphics context to draw to
d - the drawing model to get rendering information from (layers, colors, etc.)
